content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: well done

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very well suited for a clash.
As others, I would have chosen a different coordinate system, in particular not one where south positive and north negative, nor one where the y coordinate is given before the x coordinate. However, your problem statement is unambiguous and these are the little details we just have to look out for in a clash.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I gave it a try in the IDE and it felt like a good clash. The one typo I found has been fixed by the author

Thanks for taking the time to change the x and y to fit conventions! I just tested the clash in IDE and ran into another problem: the Goal statement says the south west corner is 10 0, but the constrains say y<=9. I take it the "10" in the Goal statement should be changed to "9"?

Apart from that, I was able to solve it in a reasonable time, and it's a good clash IMO. I also like your reference solution, that's some pretty clever use of booleans and the "*" operator! I learned a new trick :)

Hi @Poxknot,
I simply suggest to disambiguate your first line in the Inputs like one of these options :
-> "The starting position {x} and {y}, two integers separated by a blank space"
OR "The starting position {y} and {x}, two integers separated by a blank space" ...
Bye !
It looks really fun but the X that goes on the north/south axis tricks my brain.
It seems fun, well done

I am *very* confused. Here's the final program I've reached (in Python 3):

```
y, x = [int(i) for i in input().split()]
n = int(input())
for i in range(n):
    h = input()
    if h == "n":
        y = (y - 1) if y > 0 else 1
    elif h == "s":
        y = (y + 1) if y < 9 else 8
    elif h == "w":
        x = (x - 1) if x > 0 else 1
    elif h == "e":
        x = (x + 1) if x < 9 else 8

print(y, x)
```

Note something very important: *I've had to reverse Y and X in the input and output for the program to return something accepted by the tests*. By looking at your code, I'm even more confused, since you change the X coordinate for north and south, and the Y coordinate for west and east.

The Y coordinate is usually used for north and south, and the X coordinate is usually used for west and east. Nothing in the clash gives any information about this. Is this a confusion on your part, or a bad assumption on my part? I don't understand how we've arrived to this situation.

Goal
* "Roomba" seems to be a registered trademark, and I guess not everyone knows what that is. Suggest to change it to a generic noun e.g. "robot".

* Please change "moves forward of" to "moves forward at".

Input
* Please add line numbers in <<bold>>, i.e. <<Line 1>>, <<Line 2>> and <<Next [[n]] lines>>.

* Please change "A number [[n}]" to "An integer [[n]] for the number".

Constraints
* You may delete the last constraint as it merely repeats what has been stated in Input section.

Stub generator
* Line 1: Please parse the first line as two integers instead of a single string,

* Last line: Suggest to change "xy" to "x y".

Thanks.
Thanks for th pertinent feedback !

Allow me to disagree. I thought about it when writing and the first coordinate in a matrix is often the vertical axis and north south is often associated to vetical.
Even in geographic coordinates is (latitude, longitude) which is basically (north/south, est/west).
So I think my convention is clearer for a majority. But it is interesting to see how different people approach a problem.
Maybe I could change variable name to lat long instead of x y but those being angles and not distances I don't think I would be clearer.
Anyway I changed "The north west corner is 0 0." To "The north west corner is 0 0 and the south west is 10 0" to disambiguate.
Thank you for your feedback tho
Thanks !

I didn't think it would be such an important point, but judging by the comments I was wrong.
It's the convention of my field (aircraft navigation system design) but I can understand it being different elsewhere.
So I made the change. Thanks for taking the time.

I didn't think it would be such an important point, but judging by the comments I was wrong.
It's the convention of my field (aircraft navigation system design) but I can understand it being different elsewhere.
So I made the change. Thanks for taking the time.
Yep that's totally a typo. Thanks !
Indeed if we take it as lat/long it makes more sense but as I come from game engine I'm used to x axis horizontally ( and either Y or Z vertically ).

I have to agree with Cakeisalie5 here: when the coordinates are named x and y, I expect x to denote the horizontal part and y to denote the vertical part. This was the convention in mathematics, physics and computer science through my high school and university, and also seems to be the convention in other puzzles on this site (see https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/power-of-thor-episode-1 for example). I would suggest adapting the submission to follow that convention

I didn't think it would be such an important point, but judging by the comments I was wrong.
It's the convention of my field (aircraft navigation system design) but I can understand it being different elsewhere.
So I made the change. Thanks for taking the time.

Thank you for your prompt follow-up! Two more fixes:

Input
* Please change "A integer" to "An integer".

* Please add "representing north, south, east and west respectively" to the last description.

Thanks again.
Done ! sorry for the typos
